---
title: "Lab 1: Descriptive Statistics"
subtitle: "Personality & The Big Five"
author: "Gordon Wright"
date: "2026"
format:
  revealjs:
    slide-number: true
    progress: true
    hash: true
    transition: fade
    code-line-numbers: false
    code-annotations: hover
    highlight-style: github
    width: 1280
    height: 720
    embed-resources: true
---

# Welcome to Lab 1 {.center background-color="#1a1a2e"}

## Today's Goals

::: {.incremental}
1. Get comfortable with RStudio
2. Load and inspect data
3. Reverse-score questionnaire items
4. Calculate descriptive statistics
5. Create a simple visualisation
6. Write up results in APA style
:::

::: {.notes}
Emphasise that today is about building confidence. Errors are expected and welcomed.
:::

# Move 1: RStudio Tour {.center background-color="#2d3436"}

## The Four Panes

:::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="50%"}
**Top-Left: Source**

- Where you write scripts
- Save your work here

**Bottom-Left: Console**

- Where code runs
- Immediate feedback
:::
::: {.column width="50%"}
**Top-Right: Environment**

- Your data and objects
- Watch it update!

**Bottom-Right: Files/Plots/Help**

- Navigate files
- View outputs
:::
::::

## Here it is in real life

(![RSTUDIOIDE](labs/images/rstudio.png))

## Your First Code


::: {.cell code-annotations='hover'}

```{.r .cell-code}
1 + 1
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] 2
```


:::
:::


::: {.notes}
Run this in the Console. Watch the output appear immediately.
:::

## Creating Variables


::: {.cell code-annotations='hover'}

```{.r .cell-code}
x <- 5
y <- 2
x + y
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] 7
```


:::
:::


1. Assign a value to x
2. Assign a value to y  
3. Add them together

::: {.fragment}
**Watch the Environment pane update!**
:::

## ðŸš¨ Common Error: Object Not Found


::: {.cell code-annotations='hover'}

```{.r .cell-code}
z + 1
```
:::


```
Error: object 'z' not found
```

::: {.fragment .fade-up}
**Fix:** Create the object first!


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
z <- 10
z + 1
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] 11
```


:::
:::

:::

::: {.notes}
This is one of the most common errors. The object doesn't exist because we haven't created it yet. Don't panic!
:::

# Move 2: Vectors & Functions {.center background-color="#2d3436"}

## Combining Values


::: {.cell code-annotations='hover'}

```{.r .cell-code}
scores <- c(4, 5, 3, 2, 5)
scores
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] 4 5 3 2 5
```


:::
:::


1. `c()` combines values into a **vector**
2. Store it with a meaningful name

## Basic Functions


::: {.cell code-annotations='hover'}

```{.r .cell-code}
mean(scores)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] 3.8
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
sd(scores)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] 1.30384
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
length(scores)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] 5
```


:::
:::


1. Calculate the mean
2. Calculate the standard deviation
3. Count the number of values

# Move 3: Loading Data {.center background-color="#2d3436"}

## The Personality Dataset

We'll use **Big Five personality data** with:

- 160 participants
- 5 personality items (p1â€“p5)
- Group (control vs training)
- Time (pre vs post intervention)

## Loading a CSV File


::: {.cell code-annotations='hover'}

```{.r .cell-code}
library(readr)
data <- read_csv("personality_lab.csv")
```
:::


1. Load the `readr` package
2. Read the CSV and store as `data`

::: {.callout-warning}
## Working Directory
Make sure your CSV is in the right folder, or use the full file path.
:::

## Inspecting Your Data


::: {.cell code-annotations='hover'}

```{.r .cell-code}
head(data)
str(data)
names(data)
```
:::


1. View first 6 rows
2. See structure and data types
3. List column names

## ðŸš¨ Common Error: Function Not Found


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
read_csv("personality_lab.csv")
```
:::


```
Error: could not find function "read_csv"
```

::: {.fragment .fade-up}
**Fix:** Load the package first!


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
library(readr)
read_csv("personality_lab.csv")
```
:::

:::

::: {.notes}
99% of "could not find function" errors mean you forgot library(). Always load packages at the top of your script.
:::

# Move 4: Reverse Scoring {.center background-color="#2d3436"}

## Why Reverse Score?

Some questionnaire items are **negatively worded**

- "I rarely feel anxious" (reversed)
- "I often feel anxious" (normal)

To create a valid total score, we must **reverse** the negatively-worded items.

## The Formula

For a 1â€“5 Likert scale:

$$\text{reversed} = 6 - \text{original}$$

| Original | Reversed |
|----------|----------|
| 1 | 5 |
| 2 | 4 |
| 3 | 3 |
| 4 | 2 |
| 5 | 1 |

## Reverse Scoring in R


::: {.cell code-annotations='hover'}

```{.r .cell-code}
data$rev_p4 <- 6 - data$p4
data$rev_p5 <- 6 - data$p5
```
:::


1. Create a new column `rev_p4`
2. Create a new column `rev_p5`

## Creating the Total Score


::: {.cell code-annotations='hover'}

```{.r .cell-code}
data$pers_score <- data$p1 + data$p2 + data$p3 +
                   data$rev_p4 + data$rev_p5
```
:::


::: {.callout-important}
## Critical Check
Use the **reversed** versions (rev_p4, rev_p5), not the originals!
:::

## ðŸš¨ Common Error: Wrong Items in Sum


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
# WRONG - using unreversed items!
data$pers_score <- data$p1 + data$p2 + data$p3 +
                   data$p4 + data$p5
```
:::


::: {.fragment .fade-up}
**Fix:** Always double-check you're using reversed versions:


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
# CORRECT
data$pers_score <- data$p1 + data$p2 + data$p3 +
                   data$rev_p4 + data$rev_p5
```
:::

:::

::: {.notes}
This is a real-world mistake that invalidates analyses. Always verify your scoring.
:::

# Move 5: Descriptive Statistics {.center background-color="#2d3436"}

## Overall Descriptives


::: {.cell code-annotations='hover'}

```{.r .cell-code}
mean(data$pers_score, na.rm = TRUE)
sd(data$pers_score, na.rm = TRUE)
length(data$pers_score)
```
:::


1. Mean (with missing value handling)
2. Standard deviation
3. Sample size

## Descriptives by Group


::: {.cell code-annotations='hover'}

```{.r .cell-code}
library(dplyr)

data |>
  group_by(group, time) |>
  summarise(
    mean = mean(pers_score, na.rm = TRUE),
    sd = sd(pers_score, na.rm = TRUE),
    n = n(),
    .groups = "drop"
  )
```
:::


1. Load dplyr
2. Pipe the data forward
3. Group by factors
4. Calculate summaries

## ðŸš¨ Common Error: Forgetting na.rm


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
mean(data$pers_score)
```
:::


If any value is `NA`, the result is `NA`!

::: {.fragment .fade-up}
**Fix:** Always include `na.rm = TRUE`:


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
mean(data$pers_score, na.rm = TRUE)
```
:::

:::

::: {.notes}
This is a silent killer. You won't get an error - just NA. Always use na.rm = TRUE to be safe.
:::

# Move 6: Visualisation {.center background-color="#2d3436"}

## A Simple Boxplot


::: {.cell code-annotations='hover'}

```{.r .cell-code}
library(ggplot2)

ggplot(data, aes(x = group, y = pers_score, fill = time)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(
    title = "Personality Scores by Group and Time",
    x = "Group",
    y = "Personality Score"
  )
```
:::


1. Set up the plot with aesthetics
2. Add boxplot geometry
3. Apply clean theme
4. Add informative labels

## Understanding the Output

:::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="50%"}
**What to look for:**

- Centre (median line)
- Spread (box height = IQR)
- Outliers (points beyond whiskers)
- Group differences
:::
::: {.column width="50%"}
**Questions to ask:**

- Do groups differ at baseline?
- Is there change over time?
- Which group changed more?
:::
::::

# Move 7: APA Write-Up {.center background-color="#2d3436"}

## Template

> Participants reported moderate levels of [TRAIT] overall (M = ___, SD = ___). At baseline, the control group (M = ___, SD = ___, n = ___) and training group (M = ___, SD = ___, n = ___) were similar. Following the intervention, the control group showed [minimal change / a decrease / an increase] (M = ___, SD = ___), whereas the training group showed [change description] (M = ___, SD = ___).

## Example Write-Up

> Participants reported moderate levels of personality overall (M = 3.27, SD = 0.70). At baseline, the control group (M = 3.19, SD = 0.70, n = 40) and training group (M = 3.23, SD = 0.66, n = 40) were similar. Following the intervention, the control group showed minimal change (M = 3.20, SD = 0.72), whereas the training group showed an increase (M = 3.58, SD = 0.60).

::: {.notes}
Walk through pulling numbers from the summary table. Emphasise M, SD, and n are essential.
:::

# Summary {.center background-color="#1a1a2e"}

## Today's Key Skills

::: {.incremental}
1. âœ… Navigate RStudio's four panes
2. âœ… Create variables and vectors
3. âœ… Load data with `read_csv()`
4. âœ… Reverse-score items correctly
5. âœ… Calculate grouped descriptives with `dplyr`
6. âœ… Create boxplots with `ggplot2`
7. âœ… Write APA-style descriptions
:::

## Common Errors Recap

| Error | Cause | Fix |
|-------|-------|-----|
| Object not found | Variable doesn't exist | Create it first |
| Function not found | Package not loaded | Use `library()` |
| Result is NA | Missing values | Add `na.rm = TRUE` |
| Wrong total score | Used unreversed items | Use `rev_` versions |

## Next Steps

1. Complete the **WebR practice chapter**
2. Work through the **scaffolded template** in RStudio
3. Render and submit your lab report
4. Try the **follow-on exercise** with new data

::: {.callout-tip}
## Remember
Errors are information, not failure. Every error teaches you something!
:::

# Questions? {.center background-color="#1a1a2e"}

include-after-body:
<script>
  // htmlwidgets need to know to resize themselves when slides are shown/hidden.
  // Fire the "slideenter" event (handled by htmlwidgets.js) when the current
  // slide changes (different for each slide format).
  (function () {
    // dispatch for htmlwidgets
    function fireSlideEnter() {
      const event = window.document.createEvent("Event");
      event.initEvent("slideenter", true, true);
      window.document.dispatchEvent(event);
    }

    function fireSlideChanged(previousSlide, currentSlide) {
      fireSlideEnter();

      // dispatch for shiny
      if (window.jQuery) {
        if (previousSlide) {
          window.jQuery(previousSlide).trigger("hidden");
        }
        if (currentSlide) {
          window.jQuery(currentSlide).trigger("shown");
        }
      }
    }

    // hookup for slidy
    if (window.w3c_slidy) {
      window.w3c_slidy.add_observer(function (slide_num) {
        // slide_num starts at position 1
        fireSlideChanged(null, w3c_slidy.slides[slide_num - 1]);
      });
    }

  })();
</script>
